importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The past year (2025) has seen a surge in extreme weather events globally, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscoring the urgency for improved early warning systems.

Over the past 50 years, weather, water, and climate-related hazards have caused over 2 million deaths, with 90% of these deaths occurring in developing countries, emphasizing long-term climate-related risks.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems compared to those with them.
90% of weather-related deaths over the last 50 years occurred in developing countries, highlighting the disproportionate impact of climate hazards.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being seen in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action and can save lives and protect infrastructure.
A mountain glacier collapse in Switzerland was predicted in May 2025, leading to the evacuation of Blatten, demonstrating real-time efficacy of monitoring systems.
Permafrost melt is expected to increase glacier collapses and rockfalls, reinforcing the need for robust early warning capabilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a urgent call to action for global improvement of early-warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capabilities. The report reveals that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without such systems, and that 90% of weather-related fatalities over the past 50 years occurred in developing nations. Despite progress—such as a rise in multi-hazard warning systems from 52 to 108 countries—the situation remains dire, especially in fragile and conflict-affected regions. Real-world examples, including the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, after a glacier collapse predicted in May 2025, illustrate the life-saving potential of timely alerts. As extreme weather events like floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, have intensified in 2025, the WMO emphasizes that early warning systems are not just about alerts, but about enabling communities to take early, protective action.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
